qas.question: Where are many hospital pharmacies located?

answers.text: within the premises of the hospital
within the premises of the hospital

qas.question: In what form are most hospital medications?

answers.text: unit-dose, or a single dose of medicine
unit-dose, or a single dose of medicine

qas.question: What types of pharmacy functions have begun to be outsourced?

answers.text: high risk preparations and some other compounding functions
high risk preparations and some other compounding functions
high risk preparations and some other compounding functions

qas.question: What is one factor that increases the importance of the pharmacy performing at a high level?

answers.text: The high cost of medications and drug-related technology
high cost of medications and drug-related technology

qas.question: What are some advantages of hospital pharmacies?

answers.text: Hospital pharmacies usually stock a larger range of medications, including more specialized medications
stock a larger range of medications, including more specialized medications

plausible_answers.text: within the premises of the hospital

qas.question: Where are no hospital pharmacies located?

plausible_answers.text: unit-dose, or a single dose of medicine

qas.question: What form are most hospital medications forbidden from being?

plausible_answers.text: high risk preparations and some other compounding functions

qas.question: What types of pharmacy functions have never been outsourced?

plausible_answers.text: The high cost of medications and drug-related technology

qas.question: What is one factor that decreases the importance of the pharmacy performing at a high level?

plausible_answers.text: Hospital pharmacies usually stock a larger range of medications, including more specialized medications

qas.question: What are some disadvantages of hospital pharmacies?

context: Hospital pharmacies can often be found <a0_0><a0_2><b5_0>within the <a0_1>premises of the hospital<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. <a4_0><b9_0>Hospital pharmacies usually <a4_2>stock a larger range of medications, including <a4_1>more specialized medications<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, than would be feasible in the community setting. Most hospital medications are <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>unit-dose<a1_1/>, or a single dose of medicine<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/>. Hospital pharmacists and trained pharmacy technicians compound sterile products for patients including total parenteral nutrition (TPN), and other medications given intravenously. This is a complex process that requires adequate training of personnel, quality assurance of products, and adequate facilities. Several hospital pharmacies have decided to outsource <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>high risk preparations and some other compounding functions<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> to companies who specialize in compounding. <a3_0><b8_0>The <a3_1><a3_2>high cost of medications<a3_1/> and drug-related technology<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_0/>, combined with the potential impact of medications and pharmacy services on patient-care outcomes and patient safety, make it imperative that hospital pharmacies perform at the highest level possible.
